item.title: Israel-Gaza war: Israeli forces pushing into south Gaza
item.description: The head of Israel's military says the IDF is fighting "strongly and thoroughly" in southern Gaza.

item.title: German tourist killed and Briton injured in Paris attack
item.description: The suspect tells police he was upset by "so many Muslims dying in Afghanistan and in Palestine".

item.title: Two children among four dead in New York stabbing
item.description: Two police officers were injured and the suspect was taken to hospital but later declared dead.

item.title: Snow disrupts travel as cold and icy spell persists
item.description: Thousands are still without power and cars marooned by thick snow in Cumbria, with more warnings ahead.

item.title: XL bully ban: Fears move could increase dog attacks
item.description: Unsocialised dogs may become more dangerous and other large breeds could replace XLs, says vet.

item.title: Rizz named word of the year 2023 by Oxford University Press
item.description: Slang for charisma or romantic appeal beat Swiftie and situationship in Oxford dictionary award.

item.title: Ant and Dec plead 'no more politicians' in TV jungle
item.description: The call for a break comes as Nigel Farage appears Down Under this year - following Matt Hancock.

item.title: 'Labour won't turn on spending taps' says Starmer
item.description: Sir Keir Starmer will say in a speech there will be "huge constraints" if Labour win power.

item.title: Glenys Kinnock: The political spouse who became a force in her own right
item.description: Glenys Kinnock, the wife of Neil Kinnock, became a prominent political figure in her own right.

item.title: Train strikes: When are the walkouts in December?
item.description: Train drivers are holding rolling walkouts in December in a long-running row over pay and conditions.

item.title: Infected blood: Tory rebellion expected on payouts amendment
item.description: Up to 30,000 people were given contaminated blood in the 1970s and 1980s. Thousands have died.

item.title: Gold Coast scraps 2026 Commonwealth Games bid
item.description: The event is in doubt after the state of Victoria withdrew from hosting duties over spiralling costs.

item.title: South Africa: The region where political violence is on the rise ahead of elections
item.description: The BBC's Fergal Keane returns ahead of elections next year - 30 years since apartheid ended.

item.title: The Papers: Starmer's Thatcher backlash and PM on licence fee
item.description: Monday's papers look at the Labour leader's comments, as well as speculation over the licence fee.

item.title: BBC Sound of 2024: Tyla, Last Dinner Party and Kenya Grace tipped for success
item.description: Other rising music stars up for the prize include The Last Dinner Party, Elmiene and Ayra Starr.

item.title: How weather apps are trying to be more accurate
item.description: Forecasters are continuing to offer more real-time updates and personalised recommendations.

item.title: A young couple's ordeal captivates Chinese internet
item.description: Their struggles mirror the dashed hopes of so many people confronting a slowing economy.

item.title: Record number of girls on Borders College farming course
item.description: A record number of female students have started an agriculture course at Borders College.

item.title: Beyoncé: Meet the designer who made her sparkle on tour
item.description: Hundreds of hours go into Gaurav Gupta's designs for Beyoncé, Cardi B and Megan Thee Stallion.

item.title: Could X go bankrupt under Elon Musk?
item.description: Musk's profane attack on advertisers baffled experts - without adverts, how would X survive?

item.title: Pogues, Wham! and Mariah battle to be Christmas number one
item.description: Fairytale of New York has surged since the death of Pogues' frontman Shane MacGowan.

item.title: Watch: A dusty, foggy end for power station towers
item.description: Spectators watched the partial demolition of the landmark Fiddler's Ferry power station.

item.title: Nelson Mandela's granddaughter slams "climate apartheid" by rich nations
item.description: Social activist Ndileka Mandela says "the global north is using economic and legal power to subjugate poor nations".

item.title: Liverpool FC: Friends in fateful Anfield reunion after 50 years
item.description: School best friends James and Colin lost touch in 1972 before they found each other again by chance.

item.title: Manchester City 3-3 Tottenham: Dejan Kulusevski rescues draw for Spurs
item.description: Dejan Kulusevski heads an equaliser in the 90th minute as Tottenham earn a dramatic Premier League draw against Manchester City.

item.title: Bernard Cribbins: Doctor Who pays tribute to veteran actor
item.description: The veteran actor, who died in 2022 aged 93, reprised his role as Wilfred Mott one last time.

item.title: Milford Haven: Garden ornament turns out to be live bomb
item.description: Sian and Jeffrey Edwards had always assumed the 64lb projectile in their garden was a "dummy".

item.title: UK Championship 2023: Ronnie O'Sullivan claims record-extending eighth title
item.description: Ronnie O'Sullivan becomes the oldest-ever UK champion with a 10-7 victory over Ding Junhui as he claimed a record-extending eighth title in York.

item.title: Man City 3-3 Tottenham: Erling Haaland criticises referee on social media
item.description: Manchester City striker Erling Haaland criticises referee Simon Hooper on social media over a controversial decision late in Sunday's dramatic 3-3 draw with Tottenham.

item.title: West Indies vs England: Shai Hope guides hosts to remarkable opening ODI win
item.description: West Indies captain Shai Hope hits an unbeaten 109 to guide his side to a four-wicket win over England.

item.title: Manchester City 3-3 Tottenham: Pep Guardiola and Ange Postecoglou deliver show-stopping game
item.description: Wins are proving hard to come by for Pep Guardiola and Ange Postecoglou, but entertainment is in plentiful supply.

item.title: Liverpool 4-3 Fulham: Jurgen Klopp says his team scored 'four worldies'
item.description: Jurgen Klopp says he doesn't think he has seen "a game with this amount of beautiful goals" after his Liverpool side beat Fulham in thriller.

item.title: MOTD2 analysis: How did Manchester City's 'huge' referee error happen?
item.description: Match of the Day 2's Mark Chapman, Jermaine Jenas and Leon Osman discuss the "monster mistake" made by referee Simon Hooper during Manchester City's 3-3 draw against Tottenham Hotspur.

item.title: MOTD2 analysis: Liverpool's Trent Alexander-Arnold is 'heartbeat' of team like Steven Gerrard
item.description: Match of the Day 2's Jermaine Jenas and Leon Osman discuss how it's time for the "heartbeat" of the Liverpool team, Trent Alexander-Arnold, to take up a permanent role in central midfield.

item.title: Bowen: US sets clearer red lines for Israel as ceasefire ends
item.description: If Israel kills as many in south Gaza as in the north, Biden will face some tough questions over US support for its ally.

item.title: Israel-Gaza: UK launches surveillance flights to find Hamas hostages
item.description: The UK is sending unarmed, manned aircraft over Israel and Gaza to aid rescue efforts.

item.title: 'I’m not ready to lose hope': The hostages still in Gaza
item.description: There are still over 100 hostages being held by Hamas in Gaza, including at least 16 women.

item.title: 'A very desperate situation for the population of Gaza'
item.description: The BBC's Hugo Bachega describes the situation in the south as Israel's bombardment continues.

item.title: Released Palestinians allege abuse in Israeli jails
item.description: Palestinians tell the BBC they were beaten and had dogs set on them while in Israeli detention.

item.title: Gaza's fear and anger as ceasefire ends and fighting erupts
item.description: The UN says renewed war between Israel and Hamas is "catastrophic" and a "nightmare".

item.title: Why has the Gaza ceasefire come to an end?
item.description: Both Israel and Hamas are blaming each other for violating the terms of the agreement.

item.title: Who are the released hostages?
item.description: One-hundred-and-five people captured during the 7 October attacks have been released by Hamas.

item.title: Nearly 100,000 Gaza buildings may be damaged, satellite images show
item.description: Images commissioned by the BBC reveal the damage in Gaza before the recent temporary truce started.

item.title: Blinken steps up call for Israel to spare civilians in strongest remarks yet
item.description: The top diplomat delivers the strongest US remarks yet in Israel on protecting Palestinian civilians.

item.title: Bedouin family desperate for news on teenagers held hostage in Gaza
item.description: Two Bedouin teenagers are among the last of the young hostages yet to be released by Hamas.

item.title: Mia Schem: Wounded festival-goer in Hamas hostage video freed
item.description: Mia Schem is among eight more people released from Gaza on Thursday, in a swap for Palestinian prisoners.

item.title: Liat Beinin Atzili: US citizen among 16 Hamas hostages released
item.description: Two dual US-Israeli citizens have so far been released as part of a Qatari-brokered ceasefire in Gaza.

item.title: Mortgage rates: Five ways to save money
item.description: Experts give advice for those who might be worried about their monthly mortgage payments.

item.title: What is the minimum wage and how much is it?
item.description: The national living wage will go up next April, boosting 2.7 million people's pay.

item.title: How to get a job: Six expert tips for finding work
item.description: There are 10m people out of work in the UK, so if you're searching for a job you're not alone. Here are some tips on how to get started.

item.title: What a falling inflation rate means for your finances
item.description: Falling inflation and rising wages ease cost of living pressures for some, but money is still very tight.

item.title: Energy prices: How much will you pay from January?
item.description: Use our interactive calculator to find out how much more you'll be paying for energy each month.
